PIONEER EXPERIENCES: A GENERAL QUESTIONNAIRE

A word of explanation to the persons answering this questionnaire:

It is difficult to prepare a general questionnaire on pioneer life because no individual who is asked to answer it has exactly the same experiences as another. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experiences; others may prove impossible for you to answer, so don't worry about leaving blank spaces. Use any sheets of paper if there is not sufficient space to answer the questions. Don't hesitate to give details, or describe particular events, if they help to answer the questions.

This questionnaire is intended for persons who lived in Western Canada before 1914, and may be answered by anyone who has personal experience of the pioneer years whether born in this province or not.

If more than one member of the family can answer the questions, they should write them on separate sheets or apply for a separate questionnaire.

Other Questionnaires

Saskatchewan Archives Questionnaire No. 1, entitled "Pioneer Pasts What Did Western Canadian Pioneers Eat?" is still being circulated. If you have not already answered this, and would be willing to do so, please put a check mark here ( ) and one will be sent to you.

Saskatchewan Archives questionnaires on other subjects will be prepared at a later date. Some of these are listed below. Please mark the ones you would be willing to answer.

( ) All questionnaires
( ) Pioneer health conditions
( ) Pioneer social life, sports and recreation
( ) Pioneer housing
( ) Pioneer education and churchwork
( ) Pioneer farming experience

Preservation of Questionnaires

All questionnaires will be preserved in the Saskatchewan Archives Board's Office at the University of Saskatchewan as part of the permanent record of our Province. Please send your completed questionnaire to:

Saskatchewan Archives Office,
University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Sask.
It is important to choose a question that pertains to planning life's experiences as a family. Some of the questions here will not apply to your experience; others may prove important for you to answer, so don't worry about missing topics.

If you have any questions or suggestions regarding this questionnaire, please feel free to contact us at the following address:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

Other Questions

Instructions: Answer the following questions by writing your answers in the spaces provided.

1. What is your marital status?
2. How many children do you have?
3. What is your occupation?
4. What is your education level?
5. What is your religion?

Examination of Questionnaire

All participants will be entered into a drawing for a chance to win prizes. Please complete the questionnaire and return it to the following address:

University of Saskatchewan,
Saskatoon, Saskatchewan.

9. What were your reasons for coming West?
   Times were hard in N.S. & New Brunswick and wanted to get away from it all.

10. How did you learn about the Wests? (Through other people? Reading about it? Railroad or government information?)
    Reading mostly and Government and their Plans!
11. What did your friends and relatives think of your decision to come to Western Canada?

12. Did you travel by yourself or with a party (family, friends or other group?).

With a party of friends.

13. What means of transportation did you use?

Railway to Saskatchewan, then by team and democrat.

14. What incidents of the journey West do you remember? (People you met on the way, meetings with Indians, adventures on the journey, accidents or other excitement etc.).

I don't seem to remember any worth mentioning except that we carried an anger with which we killed soils.

15. Where did you first stay when you arrived in Saskatchewan?

A day or two in Saskatchewan.

16. Where did you settle or take up land?

Sec 2a - R18 - W3rd

17. Mention any other places where you have lived since coming to Saskatchewan.

18. How did you earn a living before coming to Western Canada? How after you came?

Homesteaded in N.S., five years, operated a grain elevator.

I earned continuously since coming here.

21. Did anyone else come to Saskatchewan because of your recommending it as a place to settle?
Yes I can think of someone

Two brothers came when I did
A sister and my mother came later

23. Is there any particular experience of pioneer days that stands out in your memory which you would like to record?
Yes, all odd numbered sections in this town belonged to the CPR. This land was selling for three dollars an acre, an American form. Machinery bought at that price and raised it to ten and fifteen per acre. Settlers who bought were loaded with debt for years. Some had to sell to get from under.

34. Did any people move away from your district prior to 1914? What reasons did they have for moving?

By this time many English settled in Theo and surrounding townships, most of them proved up and sold out, then moved to towns.

35. Did many people move away during the 1930's? Did many return?

Some young people left few if any returned.

36. If you or some member of your family have held public office, or have been active in any organizations, mention it here, giving dates wherever possible.

I organized the Local Improvement club and served as councillor, then organized Muncipality #468 and served as RUTC. Was a school trustee for about twenty years, organized the Cooperative Elevator at Theo, served as school board director 12 years.
